metadata.title: Photoinitiated Polymerization-Induced Self-Assembly of Glycidyl Methacrylate for the Synthesis of Epoxy-Functionalized Block Copolymer Nano-Objects

sections.text:
Communication Macromolecular Rapid Communications
wileyonlinelibrary.com (1 of 7) 1700195© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim DOI: 10.1002/marc.201700195
copolymer nano-objects with a diverse set of morphologies.[6] However, this method is typically conducted in dilute solution (<1%) via postpolymerization processing steps (e.g., dialysis, pH switch), which is difficult to implement on a large scale.
Over the past seven years or so, polymerization-induced self-assembly (PISA) has become an elegant, well-established method to prepare block copolymer nano-objects at high solids content (10%–50%).[7–10] Reversible addition–fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT)-mediated dispersion polymerization is the most commonly employed PISA strategy to prepare a diverse set of morphologies (e.g., spheres, worms, vesicles). The reaction media can be water,[11–15] alcohol, or alcohol/water,[16–24] ionic liquid,[25] and nonpolar solvents,[26–28] demonstrating the versatility of this approach.
Despite the tremendous progress made in the PISA area, however, the core-forming block generally lacks functionality. One possible strategy to introduce functionality is copolymerizing a small fraction of functional monomers with core-forming monomers.[29,30]
Herein, a novel photoinitiated polymerization-induced self-assembly formulation via photoinitiated reversible addition–fragmentation chain transfer dispersion polymerization of glycidyl methacrylate (PGMA) in ethanol–water at room temperature is reported. It is demonstrated that conducting polymerization-induced self-assembly (PISA) at low temperatures is crucial for obtaining colloidal stable PGMA-based diblock copolymer nano-objects. Good control is maintained during the photo-PISA process with a high rate of polymerization. The polymerization can be switched between “ON” and “OFF” in response to visible light. A phase diagram is constructed by varying monomer concentration and degree of polymerization. The PGMA-based diblock copolymer nano-objects can be further cross-linked by using a bifunctional primary amine reagent. Finally, silver nanoparticles are loaded within cross-linked vesicles via in situ reduction, exhibiting good catalytic properties.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Block copolymer nano-objects have attracted much attention due to their broad applications in the areas of cataly sis,[1] imaging,[2] therapy,[3] biomineralization,[4] and sensing.[5] Solution self-assembly of block copolymers is the most commonly used method to prepare block
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2017, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201700195
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.advancedsciencenews.com 1700195 (2 of 7)
Recently, several groups have tried to explore functional core-forming monomers that are suitable for PISA. For example, An and co-workers[31] reported an alcoholic PISA formulation using 2-(acetoacetoxy)ethyl methacrylate as the core-forming monomer with pure vesicles being obtained. The vesicles could be further functionalized or cross-linked via keto-alkoxylamine chemistry. They also demonstrated the in situ formation of silver nanoparticles within the vesicles. An and co-workers[32] also developed an aqueous PISA formulation of diacetone acrylamide for the synthesis of ketone-functionalized polymer nano-objects. Uniform vesicles were achieved by tuning reaction parameters. Huang et al.[33] reported the PISA of 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzyl methacrylate for the preparation of salicylaldehyde-functional diblock copolymer nano-objects. The obtained polymer nano-objects were further cross-linked or modified with fluorescent dyes using hydrazine.
Glycidyl methacrylate (GMA) is a commodity mono mer that has been widely used in the areas of coating, catalysis, biomedical analysis, biomolecular separation, gene delivery, etc.[34–39] The epoxy moiety can be functionalized with alcohols, thiols, amines, or proteins.[40–42] However, it is really surprising that using GMA as the core-forming monomer of PISA has never been reported before. We assume this may be attributed to the high reaction temperature (typically 70 °C) for most PISA formulations, which restricts the efficient packing of PGMA chains, since the glass transition temperature (Tg) of PGMA (45 °C) is much lower than the reaction temperature.[43] Initial experiments of PISA of GMA in ethanol or ethanol/water (80/20, w/w) at 70 °C further confirmed this assumption, with only precipitates being obtained (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Increasing the water content to 50% led to the formation of homogenous solution, which can be ascribed to the hydrolysis of GMA at such high temperature.[44] Fortunately, the recent development of photoinitiated polymerization-induced self-assembly (photo-PISA) by Boyer and co-workers,[45–47] Cai and co-workers,[48,49] and Tan et al.[50–52] has enabled the preparation of polymer nano-objects at room temperature or lower.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Herein, we report a photo-PISA formulation via photoinitiated RAFT dispersion polymerization of GMA in ethanol/water mixtures at room temperature, as shown in Scheme 1. The obtained polymer nano-objects can be further cross-linked using ethylenediamine. The macroRAFT agent was synthesized by esterification of 4-cyano4-(dodecylsulfanylthiocarbonyl) sulfanylpentanoic acid (CDPA) and monomethoxy poly(ethylene glycol) (mPEG45)
in anhydrous dichloromethane. 1H NMR spectroscopy confirmed an esterification efficiency of 95% (Figure S2, Supporting Information). 2,4,6-Trimethylbenzoyl-diphenylphosphinate (TPO) was used as the photoinitiator, which can decompose rapidly under 405 nm visible light irradiation.[52]
Kinetics studies of photo-PISA of GMA were conducted in ethanol–water mixtures when targeting a degree of polymerization (DP) of 100 for the core-forming block with a GMA concentration at 10% w/w (Figure 1a). It is apparent that higher water content in the reaction led to faster polymerization kinetics. This can be explained by the reason of greater partitioning of GMA monomer within micelles at higher water content.[53] High monomer conversion (>95%) was achieved after 40 min of visible light irradiation (405 nm, 0.46 mW cm−2) at an ethanol/water ratio (w/w) of 40/60. To the best of our knowledge, this is the fastest PISA formulation of methacrylate in alcohol or alcohol–water mixtures. A control experiment of photo-PISA of GMA was also conducted in the absence of TPO, and no polymerization was observed after 60 min of visible light irradiation (data not shown). These results indicate that the self-initiation of RAFT agent can be ignored under our reaction conditions. The high rate of polymerization can be attributed to the fast decomposition of TPO via the exposure of 405 nm visible light, as reported in our previous work.[52] In this paper, an ethanol/water ratio (w/w) of 40/60 was utilized unless otherwise stated. The semilogarithmic plot in Figure 1b shows two distinct regimes, which is similar to literature.[52,53] The first regime is from 0 to 13.9 min (the blue line), corresponding to the formation of dissolved PGMA chains. In the second regime (the red line), a fivefold increase in the rate of polymerization was observed at around 33% conversion, which corresponds to the onset of micellar nucleation. At this point, unreacted GMA monomer enters into micellar cores to solvate the PGMA chains, which produces relatively high monomer concentration in the micellar cores and the observed rate

© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimwww.advancedsciencenews.com (3 of 7) 1700195
enhancement. Samples extracted during the kinetic study were also analyzed by tetrahydrofuran (THF) gel permeation chromatography (GPC), which confirmed the linear evolution of Mn with monomer conversion (Figure 1c). These results indicate a well-controlled pseudo-living RAFT polymerization. Low molecular weight distributions were observed throughout the polymerization. Mw/Mn values were around 1.20 at low monomer conversions and increased to 1.30 at 95% monomer conversion. Figure 1d shows GPC traces obtained for mPEG45–CDPA and a series of mPEG45–PGMAn diblock copolymers prepared by photo-PISA of GMA at a monomer concentration of 20% w/w. In all cases, more than 90% monomer conversions were observed. Increasing the DP of the PGMA block led to a monotonic increase in the GPC traces of the diblock copolymer. Low molecular weight distributions (Mw/Mn < 1.25) were observed in all cases, regardless of whether the polymer nano-objects were worms, mixed morphologies, or vesicles.
To demonstrate that the photo-PISA of GMA can be temporally controlled, we exposed the polymerization mixture to alternating “ON/OFF” cycles of external light stimulation. Samples extracted during this process were analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy and THF GPC immediately. As shown in Figure S4a (Supporting Information),
both the conversion and Mn increased during the first 8 min ON cycle. There was no further conversion or molecular weight increase when the reaction was kept in dark for 6 min. Exposure to visible light for another 6 min led to increased conversion and Mn. The second and third cycles further demonstrated the fidelity of this process. Figure S4b (Supporting Information) confirmed that the evolution of Mn with GMA monomer conversion was linear, and the polydispersity of the final block copolymer was relatively low (Mw/Mn = 1.31). These results demonstrated that the pseudo-living character of polymerization was maintained during the “ON/OFF” cycles.
As mentioned in the Introduction, reaction temperature is a crucial parameter for preparing PGMA-based diblock copolymer nano-objects via PISA. The half-life of photoinitiator is independent on the reaction temperature.[54] Thus, the photo-PISA is a suitable approach to investigate the sole effect of reaction temperature on PISA. Photo-PISA of GMA in ethanol/water (40/60, w/w) was conducted at different temperatures (target DP of 200). It was found that polymerizations were stable when the reaction temperature was 50 °C or lower, which is close to the Tg value of PGMA. Similar GPC profiles were obtained under these conditions (Figure S4c, Supporting Information). In contrast, only precipitates were formed
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2017, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201700195
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.advancedsciencenews.com 1700195 (4 of 7)
when the temperature was increased to 55 °C or higher. The polymer prepared at 55 °C can be fully dissolved in THF, indicating that the precipitation was not caused by cross-linking. A possible explanation is that the high reaction temperature enhances the mobility of PGMA chains significantly, and thus leads to the formation of loose aggregates, which cannot be stabilized by the stabilizer effectively.
In PISA, a soluble macro-RAFT agent is chain extended to form a diblock copolymer. As the polymerization
proceeds, the diblock copolymers grow to a certain length and then precipitate from the solvent to form micelles. The morphology of diblock copolymer prepared via PISA is dictated primarily by the relative volume fractions of the constituent blocks (packing parameter, P), as shown in Scheme 2. Generally, spherical particles are expected when P is ≤1/3, while worms and vesicles are expected for 1/3 ≤ P ≤ 1/2 and 1/2 ≤ P ≤ 1, respectively.[9] A further series of mPEG45–PGMAn diblock copolymer nano-objects were prepared via photo-PISA, in which the DP of PGMA block and the monomer concentration were varied in order to construct a phase diagram, as shown in Figure 2. The final compositions of the diblock copolymers were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The morphology of the block copolymer nano-objects is strongly concentration-dependent, with spheres being obtained at low monomer concentrations (15% w/w or lower). In contrast, equilibrium vesicular morphologies were formed at high monomer concentrations (15% w/w or higher). This can be attributed to the increased probability of fusion between sphere–sphere under these conditions. Moreover, the high monomer concentration also allowed the core-forming block being swelled with monomer
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2017, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201700195
Scheme 2. Schematic of the preparation of diblock copolymer nano-objects by polymerization-induced self-assembly.
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimwww.advancedsciencenews.com (5 of 7) 1700195
effectively, which has proved to be a key factor for the formation of high order morphologies.[16] Similar to literature,[51,55] the pure worm phase is also very narrow and is bounded by mixed phases in the present case. It should be noted that pure worms can be easily prepared by photo-PISA because the reaction temperature is low enough to observe the significant viscosity change during the polymerization.[46,52]
Functionalization or cross-linking is desirable to enhance the performance of block copolymer nano-objects (e.g., mechanical stability, surfactant-resistant).[29,31–33,56] The mPEG45–PGMAn diblock copolymer nano-objects prepared in the present case contain a high density of epoxy functionality in the core. 1H NMR analysis indicated that the epoxy groups (>98%) were survived after the photo-PISA process (Figure S5, Supporting Information). Thus mPEG45–PGMAn diblock copolymer nano-objects can be further functionalized or cross-linked with thiols, amines, or even proteins. As a proof of concept experiment, mPEG45–PGMA70 worms and mPEG45–PGMA194 vesicles (prepared at 20% w/w GMA concentration) were treated with ethylenediamine (EDA) in an ethanol/ water mixture (40/60, w/w) at room temperature for 24 h (GMA/EDA molar ratio = 2.0). The samples were purified by centrifugation–redispersion cycles to remove
excess EDA. To demonstrate that the polymer nano-objects are indeed cross-linked after the reaction with EDA, the samples were then dispersed in THF, a good solvent for both mPEG45 and PGMA. TEM images confirmed that both the morphologies of worms and vesicles are maintained (Figure 3a,b). These results indicated that the polymer nano-objects were cross-linked after the treatment with EDA. Figure 3c shows Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of mPEG45–PGMA194 vesicles before and after the reaction. Absorption peaks at 847 and 907 cm−1 (belonging to the epoxy group) disappeared after the reaction, confirming the conversion of epoxy group. An absorption peak at 1585 cm−1 appeared after the reaction indicated the presence of primary amine group.
Deposition of inorganic nanoparticles onto polymer nano-objects is an attractive strategy to prepare inorganic/organic materials.[57–60] The primary amine group on the cross-linked PGMA nano-object can be utilized to attach heavy metal nanoparticles. Silver nanoparticles were formed in situ on the cross-linked mPEG45–PGMA194 vesicles by the reduction of AgNO3 using NaBH4, as shown in Figure 3d. The color of the dispersion changed from white to brownish after the addition of NaBH4 (Figure S6, Supporting Information). UV–vis measurement further confirmed the formation of silver nanoparticles with an
Macromol. Rapid Commun. 2017, DOI: 10.1002/marc.201700195
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.advancedsciencenews.com 1700195 (6 of 7)
absorption band at around 414 nm (Figure 3e). The catalytic property of the Ag/mPEG45–PGMA194 vesicles was then investigated by the reduction of methyl blue (MB) using NaBH4. It should be noted that without the addition of Ag/mPEG45–PGMA194 vesicles, the color of MB and NaBH4 solution remained unchanged. After the addition of Ag/mPEG45–PGMA194 vesicles, the color of the reaction mixture became pale gradually and vanished eventually. UV–vis spectra of the mixture at different times demonstrated the reduction of MB, with the characteristic peaks of MB at 615 and 665 nm being decreased with time, as shown in Figure 3f.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we have developed a novel photo-PISA formulation using GMA as the core-forming monomer. PGMA-based diblock copolymer nano-objects with tunable morphologies were prepared by varying the DP of PGMA block and the monomer concentration. The obtained epoxyfunctionalized polymer nano-objects were further crosslinked by treating with EDA under mild conditions. Finally, the cross-linked vesicles were loaded within silver nanoparticles by the in situ reduction of AgNO3. The low temperature property of photo-PISA is important to overcome the low Tg problem of PGMA. We expect that this strategy will be useful for the synthesis of a variety of diblock copolymer nano-objects with low Tg core-forming blocks.
